section.title: Atomicity for ALLOCATE and DEALLOCATE
section.t: Both ALLOCATE (see ) and DEALLOCATE (see ) are sent to the metadata server, which is responsible for coordinating the changes onto the storage devices. In particular, both operations must either fully succeed or fail, it cannot be the case that one storage device succeeds whilst another fails.

section.title: Sharing of stateids with NFSv4.1
section.t: A NFSv4.2 metadata server can hand out a layout to a NFSv4.1 storage device. Section 13.9.1 of discusses how the client gets a stateid from the metadata server to present to a storage device.

section.title: NFSv4.2 as a Storage Protocol in pNFS: the File Layout Type
section.t: A file layout provided by a NFSv4.2 server may refer either to a storage device that only implements NFSv4.1 as specified in , or to a storage device that implements additions from NFSv4.2, in which case the rules in apply. As the File Layout Type does not provide a means for informing the client as to which minor version a particular storage device is providing, the client will have to negotiate this with the storage device via the normal RPC semantics of major and minor version discovery. E.g., as per Section 16.2.3 of , the client could try a COMPOUND with a minorversion of 2 and if it gets NFS4ERR_MINOR_VERS_MISMATCH, drop back to 1.

section.title: Operations Sent to NFSv4.2 Data Servers
section.t: In addition to the commands listed in , NFSv4.2 data servers MAY accept a COMPOUND containing the following additional operations: IO_ADVISE (see ), READ_PLUS (see ), WRITE_SAME (see ), and SEEK (see ), which will be treated like the subset specified as "Operations Sent to NFSv4.1 Data Servers" in Section 13.6 of .
Additional details on the implementation of these operations in a pNFS context are documented in the operation specific sections.
